topic.title: HPE Helion Development Platform 2.0: MySQL Integration for Developers
topic.shortdesc: Create a MySQL database service and bind it to an application.

body.p: These steps are intended for developers who intend to create a custom MySQL service and bind it to an application. The administrator procedure must be completed prior to this point.

ol.li:
Bind to MySQL service from an app during deployment.
Log in to the ALS clusterhelion target <ALS cluster end point> helion login Example:$ helion target api.15.124.133.173.xip.io Successfully targeted to [https://api.15.124.133.173.xip.io] Target: https://api.15.124.133.173.xip.io Organization: <none> Space: <none> $ helion login Attempting login to [https://api.15.124.133.173.xip.io] Username: myuser@mycompany.com Password:Successfully logged into [https://api.15.124.133.173.xip.io] demo@hpe.com Choosing the one available organization: "default" Choosing the one available space: "default" Target: https://api.15.124.133.173.xip.io Organization: default Space: default
Bind to MySQL service from an app during deployment using the manifest file.
List the MySQL service in the services block of the application manifest file.
Sample manifest file including a reference to a MySQL service: my-mysql-db-service applications: .: name: my-app mem: 128M services: my-mysql-db-service: mysql helion: env: ENV_VAR: ${name} When an application is deployed in the ALS cluster, the service connection credentials are set as defined in the MySQL service gateway. The credentials become available in the VCAP_SERVICES environment variables, which can be consumed by your application. You do not need to hardcode connection credentials in your application code, instead parse and use the VCAP_SERVICES environment variables. More information on how to use VCAP_SERVICES can be found here.

Deploy the application.
Example, using the helion CLI. helion push -n
